thread.title: Smylie Kaufman comes from seven shots back to win first PGA title in Las Vegas
thread.title_full: Smylie Kaufman comes from seven shots back to win first PGA title in Las Vegas

title: Smylie Kaufman comes from seven shots back to win first PGA title in Las Vegas
text:
Smylie Kaufman comes from seven shots back to win first PGA title in Las Vegas 26 Oct 2015 01:01:53 
comments 
Smylie Kaufman produced an incredible final round to win his maiden PGA Tour title at the Shriners Hospitals for Children Open in Las Vegas. 
The 23-year-old American, playing his fifth PGA tournament, started the day seven shots behind overnight leader Brett Stegmaier but shot a 10-under 61 to take the title. 
Kaufman finished his round two-and-a-half hours before the final pair were done, but he watched all challengers fail to pass his clubhouse mark, with six players ending a shot behind on 15 under. 
Three birdies saw Kaufman reach the turn three under, but it was his back nine which propelled him up the leaderboard. 
Birdies at 10, 11 and 13 were followed by an eagle on the par-four 15th and the Louisiana State University alumni picked up further shots on the 16th and 18th. 
Stegmaier could only shoot a 69 - his worst round of the week - to miss out on his first tour title. 
He reached the turn one under after birdies at three and nine and a bogey on four. There was another bogey at 12 but back-to-back birdies on 15 and 16 gave him a chance at forcing a play-off. 
But when needing to birdie the par-four 18th, his attempted putt from just off the green came up short. 
Kevin Na, the 2011 winner, also had a shot at joining Kaufman on 15 under but his 15-foot putt on the last narrowly missed the hole. 
In a quote on PGA Tour's Twitter account, Kaufman said about his long wait: "That was so much more stressful than playing. Felt like I was watching LSU." 
Fellow American Patton Kizzire tied for second after a fine final-round charge of his own. 
Kizzire birdied the first, eighth, ninth, 10th, 12th, 13th, 15th and 17th for an eight-under 63. 
He was joined for a share of second by Stegmaier, Na, Germany's Alex Cejka and American duo Cameron Tringale and Jason Bohn. 
Morgan Hoffmann - who started the day in second - finished tied for 11th on 12 under after a level-par 71, while Rickie Fowler ended three shots further back. 
England's Greg Owen, who was in contention after the first round, fired his second-best round of the week to end on five under alongside Martin Laird, while Laird's fellow Scot Russell Knox was two shots better off after a closing 66. Related Sport News
